text: Some poor fellow is nursing their hangover with a bottle of alcohol, occasionally glancing up from their drunken stupor to ask passing by captains for help about what appears to be a ship they've lost.

options: naderin_ftl_startBar:See what about their ship is giving them such a hangover

text:
"Captain!" $HeOrShe sneezes uncontrollably as you come close. There's a moment as you maneuver yourself to be just out of range of the river of snot and alcohol dribbling down the front of $hisOrHer face and onto the floor.

To be sick, crying, and drunk is not the best of combinations, to put it lightly.

"You've got to help me find my ship. Please-" $HeOrShe sneezes again, and out of the corner of your eye, you notice your bodyguards take two steps back. Cowards.

"Ah. Right." $HeOrShe sniffles. "I had this most lovely ship. I called her The Luminary, because she was my light in the darkness. Me and her, so many journeys we've had together... ah."

You wait patiently for the poor fellow to blow through another round of Tri-Tachyon branded tissues. "Sorry, captain. It's just... Pirates! Pirates struck down my pride and joy, and now for all I know it's a pile of scrap in their cursed holds. So... if you would do me a favour and find out what happened to 'er, I'd at least have some sense of closure."

options: 5:naderin_ftl_findCover:Find some cover before it's too late

script:
$foundCover = true
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref showGiver
FireBest naderin_ftl_reopenMap
FireAll naderin_ftl_greetingOpts
text:
Deciding not to risk any sort of biohazard from impacting your person and landing you in the medbay for a week, you motion one of your guards to stand in front of you.

"Shields up, eh? I can't blame you for that, captain." The snot-dribbling fellow wheezes between chunks of words. "They getting hazard pay at least?"

There's no doubting that there's a Reaper missile stuffed deep inside $hisOrHer lungs, you justify to yourself. No way will you be taking the risk of facing that head on alone.

options: naderin_ftl_askLeads:Ask for the ship's last known location

script:
$askedForLeads = true
FireAll naderin_ftl_greetingOpts
Highlight $naderin_ftl_systemName $naderin_ftl_dist
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref getMapForDebrisPhase "Location: $naderin_ftl_systemName"
text:
"I lost her in the $naderin_ftl_systemName just a month or two ago. Not even that far! Just $naderin_ftl_dist lightyears away."

There's a moment of silence as $heOrShe collects $himOrHerself. "It was a good fight, it really was! Just... there was too many of them. And... I was a coward. I wasn't even at the helm when she blew!"

$HeOrShe slumps down, a hand reaching out for another Tri-Tachyon branded tissue. "We were so close to retirement too, she and I. So close."

options: naderin_ftl_askAboutBattle:"How did the battle go, exactly?"

script:
$askedAboutBattle = true
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref showGiver
FireBest naderin_ftl_reopenMap
SetTextHighlights "Apogee-class cruiser"
text:
"You want to know... fine. If you think it'll help." $HeOrShe manages a quick gulp of alcohol before $heOrShe begins to recount their tale of woe.

"It was a routine survey mission. The Luminary was perfect for the job, of course. She was an Apogee-class cruiser, and she'd seen her fair share of battles. So had I, but... those pirates. Normally, a fleet of their size'd be too slow to catch us, but they caught us by surprise as we were jumping in."

"We were too close to run, so we fought. It took us losing half the surveying fleet before we could disengage, and make a break for it. We e-burned away in a panic, and the pirates... sustained burn. Can you believe that?"

The outcome was obvious. The pirate fleet caught up eventually to the panicked survey fleet and managed to defeat the rest of the fleet in a second engagement. It was, as $heOrShe puts it, "a hopeless battle".

"I was lucky enough to escape that second fight on a Dram as it were, captain. Might have been the cowardice, luck, or both, but at least I'm here to tell the tale."

$HeOrShe takes the chance to grab yet another handful of Tri-Tachyon branded tissues before you continue.

script:
$askedAboutShip = true
SetTextHighlights Apogee
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref showShip
FireAll naderin_ftl_greetingOpts
text:
$HeOrShe drags out a battered Tri-Pad from the side. With a single swipe, The Luminary appears with little fanfare as you scrutinise the details.

"That's her, captain. The best Apogee I'd ever had." You hear a sniffle. "Rare as they are... I'm such a fool to lose her."

You note that the details appear to also contain projections on the lasting damage it would have suffered after it was lost in battle. Assuming, of course, that it was recovered rather than salvaged for parts.
notes: # I WONDER WHY SOME NEED THE .global PREFIX AND OTHERS DON'T????

script:
$askedAboutPayment = true
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref showGiver
FireBest naderin_ftl_reopenMap
FireAll naderin_ftl_greetingOpts
SetTextHighlights 50,000 "The Luminary's final fate" 100,000 "return her to me"
text: "50,000 credits if you get me news on The Luminary's final fate in this wretched sector. Or 100,000 if you recover her yourself and return her to me. Not that I have all that much hope..."

"Thank you, captain. I'll spare you no more words... Ludd knows I need another shot. Bartender!"

Just as you begin to up and leave, you suddenly feel something wrong. Warning signs blare inside your head, attuned from countless battles in fleet combat. What's coming? Assassins? A raid? Perhaps-

You stand there blankly, seeing the equivalent of a Reaper missile having blown apart the front of your clothes and turned you into a walking biohazard. 

$naderin_ftl_personName calls out from the front door just before they slink away into the streets. "Um. Sorry. We'll be in contact, yeah?" $HeOrShe flashes a smile before dashing away.

You are, of course, not at all embarrassed when the barkeep politely asks you to leave.

"Thank you, captain. I'll spare you no more words... Ludd knows I need another shot. Bartender!"

Just as you begin to up and leave, you suddenly feel something wrong. Warning signs blare inside your head, attuned from countless battles in fleet combat. What's coming? Assassins? A raid? Perhaps-

Your bodyguard suddenly steps in the way of what sounds like gunfire before you can even react. There's a moment of pin drop silence before you look up and see the state of your bodyguard.

It's a testament to the professionalism of your bodyguards, you feel, that they can somehow remain so stoic despite the mess splattered all over their face.

$naderin_ftl_personName calls out from the front door just before they slink away into the streets. "Um. Sorry about that. We'll be in contact, yeah?" $HeOrShe flashes a smile before dashing away.
options: naderin_ftl_postAccept:Continue after sending your bodyguard away for decontamination

notes: reason: mission accepted message appears before conversation exits to bar

options: naderin_ftl_decline:Decline, explaining that it's a lost cause

text:
"Oh. No, I understand. Thank you for listening, captain. It's the least you could have done for me. And, unfortunately, it's more'n anyone here's done so far!"

They breathe a wheeze of a chuckle as you leave them to their evergrowing pile of used Tri-Tachyon branded tissues. And a polite request for $himOrHer to leave from the proprietor that $heOrShe is pretending to not hear, by the looks of it.

notes: only reopen the map after viewing the ship if we've already seen it

script:
$alreadySeen = true
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref getMapForSecondDebris "Predicted Location: Debris Field"
text:
"Surprising to see this field hasn't drifted off after so long. Normally, these sort of debris fields scatter too wide to be of any use after a month or two." Your ops chief chimes in from the side, eyes glued to a screen.

A preliminary investigation reveals that the volume of debris here appears less than expected, even after accounting for attempted salvage efforts and the passage of time.

Judging from the misshapen breach cuts found between chunks of hull, the victors likely scavenged the debris field after having caught their prey.

"The defending fleet must have managed to disengage after some losses on both sides. If what we've been told is true... well, there'll be a second debris field around here in the direction the survey fleet attempted to escape to. I'd assume somewhere to hide... maybe here, $PlayerSirOrMadam."

A preliminary scan and investigation indicates that this is most likely the location where your client's survey team fought and lost a second, decisive engagement against a markedly superior pirate fleet.

"$PlayerSirOrMadam," your communications officer reports. "There's life signs in the wreckage. Orders?"
options:
naderin_ftl_sdfInteractionCont:Search for survivors
defaultLeave:Leave for now

text:
Salvage teams are sent into the wreckage, searching for survivors amidst the slowly drifting sections of metal and debris. Without any intact hulls to look through, efforts are quick and fruitful as a dozen or so survivors are recovered from hidden cryopods and sealed bulkheads.

They, of course, gratefully join your crew for free. Some recount seeing the pirates play 'games' with the survivors. From captured crewmembers being walked off the airlock, to ship batteries firing wildly at the wreckage, it's a tale that makes you surprised there were any survivors at all.

script:
$global.naderin_ftl_searched = true
SetTextHighlights $naderin_ftl_supplySystemName $naderin_ftl_supplySystemDist
Call $global.naderin_ftl_ref getMapForSupplyPhase "Location: $naderin_ftl_supplySystemName"
Call $naderin_tdd_ref updateStage
text:
While your crew do all the administrative work of assigning rooms and interviewing survivors, one such survivor reveals that they know where the pirate fleet left to.

"Bastards laughed at us," they spit. "Thought we'd been left for dead, spilled the beans like a villain on the holo-dramas. Can't wait to see their faces when you show up... It's the $naderin_ftl_supplySystemName system, captain."

Your nav officer helpfully pulls up the system on-screen, noting that it is $naderin_ftl_supplySystemDist lightyears away from your $shipOrFleet's current position.

"They've a supply cache snuck away there." The survivor continues. "We gave 'em a good fight, so they've run to lick their wounds. Don't let them."

notes: makeUnimportant unnecessary probably for this specific case: code probably already handles that by limiting importance to the stage

script: AddBarEvent naderin_tdd_mission "Speak with the quiet man at the end of the bar" "At the end of the bar, a quiet man sits alone tapping on their Tri-Pad. They glance around from time to time, clearly waiting for something — or someone."

text:
"Finally!" He breathes a sigh of relief as you approach. "Nobody's been taking me up on this opportunity, and I've been begging for days!"

"It's just like any other dead drop. Nothing special with the location, nothing special with the package. Can't understand why nobody's taking me up on this!" There's a trace of uncertainty in their voice.

They laugh unconfidently, tapping on their Tri-Pad far too much. An act, likely just to look busy. In control. But you can see it's all bravado.

And yet, for what?

"I can arrange a payment of 75,000 credits upon completion. No deadline, as long as you make the drop. And, of course, don't be seen making it. All standard stuff. That's okay with you, right?"
notes: # I bet there's an easier way to set the active person that I missed

text:
"You again?" He eyes you up and down as you approach. "Did you change your mind?"

They blink incredulously for a moment, before shaking their head.

"Let me remind you of the details. I'll tell you where to make the drop after you accept. There's no deadline, as long as you complete the drop. You'll receive a payment of 75,000 credits upon completion. And, of course, don't be seen doing the deed. This okay with you?"

options: naderin_tdd_convoAsk:"And where would I be delivering this package?"

text:
He stares at his Tri-Pad for a moment before looking back at you.

"I can't say. Confidential until you accept."

You get the feeling they don't actually know where it's supposed to be going.

There's a moment of silence before he responds.

"Am I?" They chuckle to themselves, but nobody's smiling.

options: naderin_tdd_convo2:"You look pretty nervous to me."

text:
They blink at you in another moment of silence.

It's far too long before they respond. "I can't say anything more than I already have. Are you taking the job or not?"

script:
unset $askedDetails
unset $askedNerves1
unset $askedNerves2
AdjustRepPerson naderin_harlan FRIENDLY 5
text:
They slam down their Tri-Pad, staring at you with a grin that's just far too wide.

"Yes! Thank you. Thank you, thank you, thank you! You won't regret this!" There's a flurry of handshakes and tears streaming down his face, and he's far too close for comfort.

Just as the overenthusiastic handshaking begins to feel excessively excessive, he steps back a bit, perhaps realising that dribbling snot all over your shoulder isn't making the best impression on you.
options: naderin_tdd_accept2:Ask where you're delivering the package

text:
"Ah. Right. You need to know where..." It's only a few taps later on his Tri-Pad that your own pings with a notification. "So, the package is on the way to your fleet. But, ah."

There's always something wrong, isn't there?

"Apologies. You'll need to contact someone over at Derinkuyu for the location of the drop. I'm just a middleman!"

You watch as they scurry off into some corner of the bar, ordering themselves a round of drinks before you can get a word in. 

It's only when your crew begins loading the package — a shielded crate of... something — onto your flagship that you begin to wonder just what you've gotten yourself into.
options:
naderin_tdd_badger:Demand an explanation
naderin_tdd_examine:Examine the package discreetly
backToBar:Return to the bar

text:
By the time you catch up with them, they're dead drunk.

You find it unlikely they'll be able to tell you anything of value.
options:
naderin_tdd_examine:Examine the package discreetly
backToBar:Take a look around the bar

text:
In this day and age, only the most trusting of captains agree to deliver things without checking what they're carrying. You are not one of them.

With practiced precision, your technicians and engineers crack open the shielded crate without tripping any alarms or hidden security measures. It doesn't take long to discover a custom-built miniaturized stealth relay, folded neatly and waiting to conduct any number of nefarious schemes upon its enemies.

"Hey, watch it!" You hear your chief engineer suddenly bark over comms, overeager machinery powering down in the background. "The crate was one thing, this is another. Everyone knows these things could be rigged to explode if you touch them wrong. Plus, if we break it apart... well. Scans first."
options: naderin_tdd_examine2:Watch your crew get to work

text:
It is after a few scans (and a lecture on following protocol) that your crew discover that the relay is based on already existing designs, only with significant exterior markings and modifications on top. Non-intrusive examinations of the relay's structure are as thorough as possible, but unfortunately the crew are forced to go without the gung-ho of engineering's brand new laser powered breach cutters.

"Could've sworn... no, it's fine work, but not military. Whoever made this slapped on some exterior modifications to a common, downscaled design, which reminds me of the shortcuts you'd find apprentices make on their assessments." Your chief engineer chuckles to themselves, shaking their head a little. "I suppose this level of makeshift work could plausibly pass for spaceworthy. Not that anyone in their right mind would ever consider it up to code."

It doesn't take too long for the final report to show up on your Tri-Pad.

"Looks like this is meant to just broadcast a message," your tech officer reports to you. "What message, if any, we can only know when we make the drop."

"Oh. Okay."

That's all he says to you as you walk away.
OR
"Ah. Well. That's fine."

He returns to their Tri-Pad, tapping away for reasons only they know.
options: backToBar:Take a look around the bar

text: The moment you connect, you see Remy staring at you with bloodshot eyes. Behind him, you see empty alcohol bottles littering his apartment, accompanied by soaked paper documents strewn about haphazardly.

options:
naderin_tdd_remyHello:"Hello?"
naderin_tdd_remyDetails:"I was told to call you for the details about a dead drop."
naderin_tdd_remyNothing:Say nothing

text:
They blink at you for a few seconds before suddenly sitting up in their seat, trying to regain some sense of composure.

"Ah, yes, hello! Bright stars, and all that. What are you here for?"
options:
naderin_tdd_remyHello2:"Do the words 'dead drop' ring any bells for you?"
naderin_tdd_remyDetails:"I was told to call you for the details about a dead drop."

text:
"What? Oh, it's you! Harlan sent me a message the moment you said yes."

"I wasn't expecting anyone to take on this mission after how long I'd been waiting... but now that you're here, I can finally get this thing off my back! You have no idea all the troubles I've had to go through. Getting Harlan to ask around was my last resort. After talking to all those stuck-up assholes myself—"

Remy decides at that moment to take a swig of alcohol from a bottle beside him, as if there were some metaphorical weight lifting off their shoulders.

"I really can't thank you enough. I mean it. Really."
options: naderin_tdd_remyDetails:Ask where you're delivering the drop

text:
You stare silently at them, waiting for a response. Remy simply stares back, also waiting for you to say something.

Seconds go by before you get the feeling that you should probably start talking.
options:
naderin_tdd_remyHello:"Hello?"
naderin_tdd_remyDetails:"I was told to call you for the details about a dead drop."

script:
Call $naderin_tdd_ref viewMap "Destination: $naderin_tdd_systemName"
Call $naderin_tdd_ref updateStage
FireAll naderin_tdd_remyDetailOpts
SetTextHighlights $naderin_tdd_systemName $naderin_tdd_dist
$naderin_tdd_drop = true
text:
Remy slaps their forehead. "Right! That! Why else, but... You're here to... yeah, yeah."

He leans off to the side, picking up a datapad. "If you would please go to the $naderin_tdd_systemName about $naderin_tdd_dist light-years away, and drop off the package at the location specified there..."

His voice trails off into the air. Your nav officer receives a ping moments later. Coordinates received.

"That would be perfect!" Remy beams at you with a thankful smile. "I trust you can get this done in a jiffy, despite the danger! But no rush, no rush. There's no deadline for this mission. Good luck!"
notes:
# Call viewMap is not vanilla. change required likely due to Remy not being original quest giver
# SetStoryPoint fractions found/set in settings.json
# Some of those scripts are probably unnecessary

text:
"Oh. Uh. Just a few pirates on the way, that's all. It's sort of the reason nobody wanted to take the mission." Remy chuckles to himself, as if not believing his own words.

"Nothing someone like you can't handle, though. Right?"

options: naderin_tdd_askCrew:Ask your information officer about the 'danger'

text:
Your officer taps a bit on their console, but it's clear that they already know what the danger might be about.

"There's rumours. They all seem wholly unsubstantiated, but there's something that comes up just enough that people think it could be true. It's the name, 'Kanta'."

"It's not clear how they're related. But I'd bet they're related somehow."

Your ops chief chimes in from the side. "There's every chance the rumors are all fabricated. Nothing like slandering someone on the local forums to run them out of business."

There's nothing concrete, but you realise you do have the option of just asking Remy outright.

"Uh, Kanta? That Kanta?" He blinks for a second, an eyebrow raised in thought. "If I were on her bad side, I'd be dead. And if I were on her good side, well, I wouldn't be here."

He swishes his bottle of cheap alcohol around idly. You don't have the impression that Remy's much of a good actor, but it's certainly possible that he's lying.

It's equally possible that you're overthinking this.

script: SetStoryOption naderin_tdd_askForMore 1 naderin_askedForMoney ui_char_spent_story_point "Convinced Remy to give you more credits to complete a dead drop"
options: naderin_tdd_askForMore:"Actually, that's a little far. I need more credits."

text:
The pay might already be enough to cover anyone else's expenses, but you think you could make a pretty good case as to why you of all people deserve a little extra.

"What? Why would you need...?"

You make a few vague statements, letting Remy do all the thinking in your stead. Over a matter of minutes, you slowly see his face change several times as the gears click in his brain.

"...right, right. More credits would make sense. You need fuel and supplies, and maybe a little extra as a buffer for unforeseen damages. That'd mean this would have to be an advance on the original reward. And then add some more for delivering something nobody else wanted to deliver..."
options:
naderin_tdd_askForMore3Opt1:"You're starting to understand now."
naderin_tdd_askForMore3Opt2:Stay silent
notes: # despite leading to the same dialogue, these options have to be different to prevent breaking keyboard shortcuts (i.e. the press 1 for opt 1, 2 for 2, etc.)

text:
Eventually, you see the credits enter your account. 

"That's all I can give you on top of what we've already agreed on." Remy grimaces, tapping rapidly on something off screen. "Unfortunately, I now have some pressing business to attend to on account of the gaping hole in my account, so if you'll excuse me..."

Then with a swipe of his fingers, Remy cuts off the connection. It seems he'll be busy for a while yet.

You cut the comm link.

Not a minute after does an apologetic message arrive from Remy, suddenly informing you that you'll have to return to him to recieve payment, rather than immediately upon making the drop.

You get the feeling that there'll be more unforeseen complications in the future.

Remy looks up and down at you with a frown.

"What is it? Need me to wish you bright burns, and all that?" He sighs. "I don't have anything else for you. It's up to you to make the drop, whether it be this cycle or the next. And I appreciate that you've agreed to do it in place of all the other captains that've refused, but..."

They lean in, their face taking up the entire screen.

"You ARE going to make the drop, right? Eventually?"

options:
naderin_tdd_greetAgainYes:"Of course."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainMaybe:"I'll get around to it."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainNo:"No."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainSilence:Say nothing

text:
There's a sigh of relief as they lean back into their seat.

"Right, right. You aren't the kind of space captain to renege on their promises, leaving missions incomplete. I knew you were the good sort right from the start!"

Already, you see another cheap bottle of liquor being dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

Remy blinks at you.

"Well, as long as you do it at some point, I'm happy with that. You aren't getting paid until you do it after all!"

You watch as another cheap bottle of liquor is dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

One second of silence drags out to two, then four, then eight, then sixteen...

"You're joking, right?"

Remy shakes their head. "It was just one of them rhetorical questions anyway. Well, I have business to attend to, so burn bright captain, and I'll hopefully see you later when you've done your job. Because you will do it! Right? Right!?"

They look at you, then at the bottles strewn about behind them, then again back at you.

"Okay! Anyway, I won't keep you! Bye!" It's at that very second that they begin mashing at the cut-off button, leaving you to wonder just what crazy thoughts your silence has put in their head.
Your $shipOrFleet was recently detected - or is currently being tracked by - a nearby fleet, and dropping off the shielded crate at the specified location is extremely inadvisable.

Your nav officer reports that your $shipOrFleet has arrived at the coordinates provided by $naderin_tdd_personName.

Preparations have already been made to handle whatever trouble might come out of this dead drop - notably far more than most other drops you've done before. Ship sensors are primed, guns readied, and crew on high alert.

The $naderin_tdd_thing is held gently in a cargo drone's manipulator arms, ready for deployment. The go-button flashes softly on your command interface.
options:
naderin_tdd_objectScan1:Drop it off in a stable orbit
defaultLeave:Leave

text:
The bay doors open, and the cargo drone extends its arms. Then, gently, its manipulators release.

There's a moment of bated breath as a miniaturized stealth relay unfolds itself, sliding out of the now unshielded crate. You watch the display feed as maneuvering thrusters softly glide the relay away from your flagship, and into space.

The image flickers, warbles, shakes... then nothing.

Your sensors officer looks up, a thin sheen of sweat on their forehead. "$PlayerSirOrMadam, we've lost the nav. It's gone."
notes: # generic_probe wasn't available, so I just copied it from the files and added it into the mod as vanilla_generic_probe (also involves settings.json)

text:
There's a sense of déjà vu as crew chatter quietly over comms, incredulous. Was that it? Just a souped-up civilian relay made for military-spec adventures? No trigger-happy fleets coming to claim the lives of your crew any more than usual?

"There were rumours," your sensors officer mumbles aloud to themselves. "Nobody thought it was worth the risk."
options:
naderin_tdd_objectScanSuperstitions:"Sometimes, rumors are just that. Nothing more."
naderin_tdd_objectScanWhy:"There's something coming our way, isn't there?"
naderin_tdd_objectScan3:Continue

text:
Your crew exchange glances.

"As you say, $playerSirOrMadam."
"There's nothing new on sensors, $playerSirOrMadam." Your crew exchange glances as your sensors officer double-checks their work. "I can't see any reason for concern at the moment, but..."

Just as your crew begin to second-guess themselves, a garbled hyperwave burst blares out from the relay without warning. And then, as if having fulfilled its purpose, it shudders back into view of your sensors... and then breaks apart into multiple pieces.

Your comms officer taps at their console, but they appear to make no progress. "The hyperwave message is just junk. Nothing we can sift out from the static, $playerSirOrMadam."

"That relay was junk," your chief engineer scoffs from the side. "But failing like that? I can't believe I even thought it was spaceworthy."

Salvage crews depart shortly after you give the order, and results come in promptly without issue.

"Now that we were able to take a closer look, we were able to confirm that there wasn't much of a chance of it working properly in the first place. A modified relay like this? It's like self-sabotage with how shoddy the workmanship is."

Despite this, your sensors officer notes that even if the onboard electronics were turned to slag when the thing tore itself apart, the garbled hyperwave burst was certainly still strong enough to alert any nearby fleets of your presence.

text:
"Ah. Well. It's a funny story. Sort of. More of a long story, really. Um." Remy hesitates for a second.

"Okay, yeah. It's pirates. I'm in debt to pirates."
"Yep. Pirates."
"Pirates. Yeah. Those guys."

He coughs. "I mean, sure, pirates rob and pillage and all that. They aren't in their right minds half of the time. But they're, you know, pirates. If they knew you could mug someone of credits you don't even have, well..."

"Never mind that." Remy waves a hand dismissively, not wanting to speak more of it. "The whole point of the drop was to get a message across to someone in the system. That it failed... well, that was actually on purpose."

"Ha, well, let me give you a bit of context. You see, my debt isn't really just a matter of credits. My activities here make bank, so that's not an issue."

Remy turns to the side for a moment, tapping for a second on their console. "It's a debt in the sense that I messed up one of their jobs. Now I owe them a whole slew of favours in lieu of payment. One of them being the drop."

"And that makeshift relay you deployed for me didn't really fail at all. It just pretended to. If it fooled you, then it should have fooled everyone else too, which is great. It all worked out in the end."

"Though I admit," he pauses, "the relay wasn't supposed to fail as spectacularly as it did. Well, in the sense that making something fail only for it to fail to fail... well, it's ironic, isn't it?"

"Almost. Intentional sabotage would have been far too obvious, so I had to attempt more subtle means of failure. But who knew the thing was shoddy enough to break on it's own?"

Remy shrugs. "Either way, it bought me some time. Time for... well. Enough for you to help me, if you're down for it."
